questions.text: Identify the given lesion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) We can see dendrites in the cornea which are typically seen in Viral keratitis (HSV keratitis). HZO – Varicella zoster, there are no dendrites but presence of pseudo dendrites are seen.

questions.text: Biconcave lens is used in treatment of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Biconcave lens is a divergent lens, used to correct the image forming in front of the retina in a myopic eye.

questions.text: After an accident from metal works, a mechanic got injured from metallic foreign body. Investigation of the choice is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MRI is C/I in a patient with injury by metal foreign body, it will lead the metallic foreign body to further invade into the eye. So the best investigation is CT Scan 1st investigation – B Scan

questions.text: The most common cause of blindness in children is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cataract – senile 50-60 yrs Glaucoma – 40 yrs Vitamin A deficiency – children

questions.text: Patient had a fight, following which he presents with non- reactive pupil and painful ocular movements. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Non reactive pupil can be associated with cataract if associated with phacomorphic/phacolytic/phacotoxic glaucoma. Optic neuritis – RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) – there will be non reactive pupil and pain, pain because the superior rectus muscle lies in contact with the optic nerve and there is a inflammation in optic nerve, so when the patient will lift the eyeball upaward the superior rectus muscle will contract and there will be stretch in inflammed optic nerve and will result in pain.

questions.text: Patient had a fight & is brought with non reactive pupil with painful ocular movements. Most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Optic neuritis Non reactive pupil can be associated with cataract if associated with phacomorphic/phacolytic/phacotoxic glaucoma. Optic neuritis – RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) – there will be non reactive pupil and pain, pain because the superior rectus muscle lies in contact with the optic nerve and there is a inflammation in optic nerve, so when the patient will lift the eyeball upaward the superior rectus muscle will contract and there will be stretch in inflammed optic nerve and will result in pain.

questions.text: Koeppe nodules are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iris Koeppe nodules are seen in Anterior Uveitis at the inner pupillary margin (Iris).

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Orbital floor fracture There is a break in the orbital floor we can clearly see a tear drop appearance that indicates of Orbital floor fracture.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy with intentional tremors, hepatosplenomegaly and CNS changes came to OPD. On examination on Slit lamp this picture was seen. What can be the provisional diagnosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a finding of Sunflower cataract which is typically seen in WILSON’S DISEASE. Wilson’s disease – Cu metabolism disorders, KF Ring is seen.

questions.text: S in SAFE strategy of trachoma stands for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Surgery S – Surgery A – Antibiotic prophylaxis F- Facial hygiene E- Environmental sanitation Surgery is typical for Trichiasis > Entropion

questions.text: 34-year-old male working as a Welder, came with complaint of pain, redness & watery eyes, What is the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Symptoms are indicative of Photo opthalmia. UV rays from the welding machine causes desquamation of the corneal epithelial cells which results in the epithelial defect. Management – patch the eye for 12-24 hrs

questions.text: What is the Position of lacrimal sac in the orbit?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Medial wall Position of the lacrimal sac is medial wall of the orbit.

questions.text: Which of the following is synergistic muscle of Right lateral rectus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rt. Inferior Oblique Synergistic muscle means which is helping the right lateral rectus to abduct the eye ball i.e. Rt. Inferior Oblique Oblique are Abductors, Superior are intortors, Inferior are Extortors, Recti are Adductors

questions.text: Bitemporal hemianopia indicates that the lesion is at ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic Chiasma Please check the figure below:

questions.text: Xerophthalmia causes dry eyes due to deficiency of which of the following vitamin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Xerophthalmia is due to deficiency of Vit. A because it contributes to the mucus layer of the tear film which is secreted by conjectival goblet cells, so vitamin A is required for the wellbeing of the goblet cells.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is diagnosed with anisometropic amblyopia in one eye. What will be the best treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Occlusion therapy Anisometric amblyopia – difference of refractive power of both eyes. Amblyopia- stimulus deprived loss of vision without any anatomical defect, there is just functional loss. Rx : Refraction with Occlusion

questions.text: 40-year-old male developed ptosis worsen during the day and it is improved on neostigmine. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myasthenia gravis Neostigmine – prevents degradation of acetylcholine esterase. Used in treatment of Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: Below image with diagnostic finding of cherry red spot can be seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CRAO Cherry red spot is typically seen in CRAO

questions.text: A 65 year old male underwent cataract surgery 2 years back, now coming to you with complaints of decrease in vision since 3 months. What laser is used for his treatment What laser is used for his treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a case of PCO/After cataract. It is most common late complication of cataract surgery. The laser used is Nd YAG, wavelength is 1064 Nm.

questions.text: A young patient with history of contact lens use presents with foreign body sensation, red eye with Watery discharge. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cobble stone pappilae i.e. typical feature of VKC (Spring Catarrh) more common in summers. More common in males, B/L, HSN 1 + 4 > 1 > 4, maxwel lyon sign – thick ropy discharge – eosinophils. But in this case the history of contact lens use is mentioned so,it will be Gaint Papillary Conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A farmer presented with pain, photophobia & watering from the eye for last 36 hours. On examination, an ulcer is seen as shown. Identify the lesion marked.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is dry looking ulcer and it has got fluffy margins, Satellite lesion.

questions.text: Identify the given condition with inward rolling of lid margin:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Entropion Inward rolling - Entropion Outward rolling – Ectropion Misdirected eye lashes – Trichiasis Extra row of eye lashes - Distichiasis

questions.text: A child aged 1.5 years old is brought by parents with leukocoria as shown & flexer wintersteiner rosettes. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Leukocoria – white pupillary reflex Leukocoria and flexer wintersteiner rosettes are pathognomic feature of Retinoblastoma. Mc age of diagnostic of retinoblastoma – 18 months Mcc of leukocoria – congenital cataract IOC - NCCT IOC for detecting metastasis in retinoblastoma - MRI

questions.text: A 60 year old man is being treated with antiglaucoma drug and his bronchial asthma got worsened. What could be the probable cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Timolol ß1 receptors are present on the heart ß2 receptors are present on lungs Timolol – ß1 + ß2 blocker If we give timolol it is going to constrict the bronchus and lead to asthma.

questions.text: A lady presents with grade 2 pterygium. What would be the best treatment in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Excision with conjunctival autograft Grade 1 – 2mm on the cornea Grade 2 - >2 mm upto pupillary margin Grade 3 – covering visual axis Best management – Excision with conjunctival autograft

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of floaters, flashes and then a curtain like shadow in front of the eye. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Retinal Detachment floaters – Shaffer Sign – Tobacco dust → in posterior segment, Photopsia – flashes of light. Curtain like shadow is typical finding of Retinal detachment. In retinal detachment there is white pupillary reflex called Leukocoria.

choices.text: Growth of lens capsule with age

questions.text: A child is being considered for IOL implantation, what should be kept in mind in such a case while choosing IOL power?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Myopic shift at birth – 17mm At 2 yrs – 21mm Adult – 24mm The retina will go backwards as the size of the eyeball will increase with age. The IOL implanted will still focus on the same place where it was focusing when the surgery was done, and the retina will go backwards and the child will become Myopic.

questions.text: A child from poor socioeconomic background presents with white foamy spots in both the eyes. What could be the reason
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Conjunctival xerosis Poor socioeconomic – vitamin A deficiency Vitamin A deficiency – conjunctival xerosis Foamy spots are the bitot spots seen in vitamin A deficiency, presents at the temporal part.

questions.text: A 3 year old boy presents with itching and red eyes which is more in summer. There is also ropy discharge from the eyes. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spring catarrah Cobble stone pappilae i.e. typical feature of VKC (Spring Catarrh) more common in summers. More common in males, B/L, HSN 1 + 4 > 1 > 4, maxwel lyon sign – thick ropy discharge – eosinophils.

questions.text: A girl uses the contact lens shared by another person and develops painful red eye. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pseudomonas infection The most common infection associated with the contact lens users is Pseudomonas infection. But if the patient is having history of swimming in pond with contact lenses on – Acanthameoba keratitis.

questions.text: The following are the findings of a patient when retinoscopy done at a distance of 1 meter and under Homatropine. ( +3.50 at X axis & + 2.50 at Y axis) What will be the glass prescription in this case.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) +2.50 D Sph +1.00 D cyll 180 deg 1 meter = deduct -1 , Homatropine = deduct – 0.5 Deduct – 1.5 from both axis

questions.text: An elderly man who is one-eyed got punched in his only seeing eye. He presents with painful decrease in vision, what could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic neuritis – RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) – there will be non reactive pupil and pain, pain because the superior rectus muscle lies in contact with the optic nerve and there is a inflammation in optic nerve, so when the patient will lift the eyeball upward the superior rectus muscle will contract and there will be stretch in inflamed optic nerve and will result in pain.

questions.text: A patient suffers trauma with vegetative matter and presents with ulcer with hypopyon and satellite lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fungal keratitis This is dry looking ulcer and it has got fluffy margins, Satellite lesion typically found in Fungal Keratitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with hard painless nodule growing externally away from lid margin. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Chalazion Painless nodule is CHALAZION. Chalazion – Lipogranulomatus inflammation of Meibomian Gland Rx: I & D (Incision and drainage)

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral ptosis which is variable during the day and reduces on putting the ice packs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Myasthenia gravis Dx: Myasthenia Gravis Putting the ice pack would actually paralyze the enzyme acetylcholine esterase as a result the concentration of the acetylcholine will remain in the synaptic junction for longer duration of time as a result patient will get improvement in signs and symptoms.

questions.text: A young boy suffered blunt trauma and develops monocular diplopia. What could be the reason?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Because of the tearing of the pupil at its root there is another pupil (D shaped pupil), now the image will be entering into the eye from the previous pupil and the another pupil formed, so there will be 2 pupil i.e. Iridodialysis.

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstay of the management of trachoma. What does the S in this acronym mean?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Surgery Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the drug of choice and surgery improves the correction of trichiasis and entropion.

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nd-Yag laser The given clinical scenario is suggestive of After-cataract. A posterior capsulotomy using an Nd:YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. Posterior capsular opacification, also called as after-cataract or secondary cataract is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female patient has had a diabetic cataract for the past 3 months. Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sorbitol + fructose A diabetic cataract occurs due to sorbitol + fructose accumulation within the lens. In diabetic patients, increased levels of blood glucose lead to high levels of glucose in the aqueous humor. The excess glucose in the aqueous humor is metabolized into sorbitol through polyol pathway by the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol is then converted to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase, but at a much slower rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Left medial rectus Yoke muscles are also known as contralateral synergists. They are pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during conjugate movements. Eg Right MR and Left LR; Right LR and Left MR

questions.text: Fundoscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CRAO The given image showing cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Fundus shows interrupted flow in vein known as cattle track appearance. Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by i.v acetazolamide or ocular massage.

questions.text: In relation to which wall of the orbit is the canaliculi that opens into the lacrimal sac present?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Medial wall The canaliculi that open into the lacrimal sac are present in relation to the medial wall of the orbit.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is cauliflower like growth in the left eye along with leukocoria and an absent red reflex. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the causative gene in the given condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rb gene The clinical history points toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma which occurs due to a mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14. Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who was using presbyopic glasses for the past few years is now able to comfortably read the newspaper without the glasses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Index myopia Index myopia occurs due to an increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens due to nuclear sclerosis. Nuclear sclerosis is an ageing process in which the lens becomes hard and inelastic, resulting in an increase in refractive index, causing progressive myopia (decreased distant vision). A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles. This improvement in vision is termed second sight.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Removal by 26G needle The given history is suggestive of superficial foreign body to the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in management of this patient. Cases of ferruginous intraocular foreign body (IOFB) may give rise to anterior capsular cataracts and reddish-brown staining of the iris leading to heterochromia iridis. MRI is contraindicated here and instead, CT is used to localise metallic IOFB.

questions.text: Sudden loss of vision with no fundal glow, there is no history of trauma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Sudden Painful loss of vision with mid dilated & fixed pupil:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: History of intake of ATT with loss of vision. Most probable drug is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Va of right eye is 6/36. Difference in refractive powers in 2 eyes- +5D in one eye and + 1D in another eye. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: History of Blunt trauma ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: There is a history of ear surgery after which the patient had developed Lagophthalmos. It is due to involvement of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Curtain falling sign is seen in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the local anaesthetic
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is the corrected refractory error:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Cherry red Spot is Seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Normal flora in conjunctiva
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Visual acuity <3/60 in Better eye with best correction
Visual acuity <6/60 in better eye with available correction
Visual acuity <1/60 in Better eye with best correction
Visual acuity <3/60 in any eye with available correction

questions.text: What is the definition of blindness s per WHO:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: What is anisometropia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A labourer working in construction site had chuna particle fall in eye. How will you manage initially?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is not function of superior oblique?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The superior oblique muscle has three main functions, which are often remembered by the acronym SAD: Superior oblique Abducts (moves the eye away from the nose) Depresses (moves the eye downward) Intorts (rotates the top of the eyeball toward the nose) Since adduction (moving the eye toward the nose) is the opposite of abduction, it is not a function of the superior oblique muscle. The medial rectus muscle is the primary muscle responsible for adduction.

questions.text: A patient of Rheumatic heart disease with superior visual field defect. What could be the possibility
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: 40yr old patient wearing thick spectacles since childhood came with complaints of sudden onset flashes. What could be likely cause for which treatment is needed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following is most common cause of unilateral proptosis in adults?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: A and B wave amplitude are reduced in Electroretinogram
Night blindness is seen in late stages

questions.text: Which is false for the given image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 2 month old child with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 80 yr old male presented with diminuition of vision since 2 yrs. The right eye was red and painful. On examination, the IOP was 50 mmHg in left eye and 16 mm Hg in right eye. The right eye had deep anterior chamber with some cells and flare. What could be the possibility?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Disease causing paresis of LPS or Muller's muscle and lagophtalmos eventually leading to blindness
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following types of cataract would be present in a patient after a blunt trauma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rosette cataract A rosette cataract typically follows closed globe injuries (blunt trauma). In blunt trauma, there may be minute ruptures in the lens capsule resulting in an influx of aqueous humor, leading to hydration and subsequent opacification of the lens. Commonly there is posterior subcapsular opacification in a flower shape along the posterior sutures. Hence it is called rosette cataract.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acanthamoeba The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba. Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine- like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with complaints of itching and a foreign body sensation in his eye. Upon examination, a shield ulcer is observed. The condition commonly associated with these findings is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Spring catarrh Considenng the symptoms of itching and foreign body sensation in the eye, and the presence of a shield ulcer, the most likely condition in this context is Spring catarrh. Spring catarrh, or vernal keratoconjunctivitis, is a chronic form of allergic conjunctivitis. It typically occurs seasonally, often in the spring and summer. It presents with symptoms such as itching, foreign body sensation, and mucous discharge. While shield ulcers are not the primary feature of spring catarrh, severe and chronic cases may lead to corneal complications, including ulcers.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of childhood blindness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vitamin A deficiency The most common cause of preventable childhood blindness is vitamin A deficiency. The most common cause of blindness in adults, is however, cataract. Vitamin A deficiency is a major cause of childhood blindness, particularly in developing countries. Lack of sufficient vitamin A can lead to conditions like xerophthalmia, which includes night blindness and can progress to more severe forms, ultimately causing irreversible damage to the cornea and leading to blindness.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of blurring of vision. On examination, you note that there are aqueous flares with numerous keratic precipitates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iridocyclitis The features of aqueous flares and keratic precipitates indicate a diagnosus of Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI). Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. It is normally seen in middle-aged people who may complain of symptoms such as blurring of vision and persistent floaters.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with glaucoma. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prostaglandin analogues The class of anti-glaucoma drugs which act by increasing the uveo-scleral outflow are prostaglandin analogues. Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog and a commonly used medication for glaucoma. Prostaglandin analogs are often preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing convenience.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is shown in the image below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lim’s forceps The instrument shown in the image above is Lim’s forceps. Lim’s forceps are a type of surgical instrument used in ophthalmic procedures. They are designed for delicate manipulations within the eye during surgery. These forceps typically have fine tips and a delicate grip, allowing surgeons to handle delicate tissues with precision.

questions.text: A child presents with There is a history of watering from his right eye since birth Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sac massage with topical antibiotics The image shows right-sided swelling in the lacrimal sac area along with watering of the eye is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis. Treatment for a 3-month-old child includes sac massage with topical antibiotics. More than 90% of patients with congenital nasolacrimal obstruction undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female who is on antitubercular therapy (ATT) experiences red-green color discrimination issues. Which of the following ATT drugs is most likely responsible for this side effect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ethambutol The most likely ATT drug responsible for the red-green color discrimination issue in this case is ethambutol. It is important to monitor patients on this drug for visual side effects and, if necessary. Consider dosage adjustments or discontinuation under medical supervision. Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in, disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. It is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child visited the ophthalmologist exhibiting a white eye reflex, and ultrasonography revealed an intraocular mass with calcifications. The family history indicated that the child’s father had a similar condition and underwent the removal of one eye (enucleation). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retinoblastoma The clinical history of leukocoria, an intraocular mass with calcifications on ultrasound, and a positive family history, the most likely diagnosis is retinoblastoma (option c). Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that predominantly affects children, and early detection and treatment are crucial for better outcomes. Point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of using contact lenses, presented with pain, redness and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer was noted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon and a moderate flare reaction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bacterial corneal ulcer Hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens) is typically caused by Pneumococcus. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the centre of the cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complete anopia in the right eye. The lesion would be present in which specific anatomical structure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right optic nerve The most likely site of the lesion causing unilateral complete anopia in the right eye is © Right optic nerve. This suggests that there is a problem affecting the visual information from the right eye before the optic chaisma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Goldmann applanation tonometer Goldmann applanation tonometer is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. It is based on Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A). P = W/A The different types are Goldmann tonometer, Perkin’s tonometer, pneumatic tonometer, pulse air tonometer, tono-pen.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. He underwent a cataract surgery 1 month ago. The patient’s fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed a flower-petal appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cystoid macular edema The given scenario of a diabetic patient with the blurring of vision and an FFA showing a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region. CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle’s layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.

questions.text: During a dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), which of the following bones are typically removed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lacrimal During a dacryocystorhinostomy, a portion of the lacrimal bone is typically removed to create a passage for tear drainage. The lacrimal bone is indeed a key bone involved in dacryocystorhinostomy. In this procedure, a portion of the lacrimal bone is often removed to create a passage for tear drainage.

questions.text: The fundoscopy findings of a known case of HIV with low CD4 counts in shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ganciclovir The above image depicts “sauce and cheese” retinopathy, which is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis, Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following cataract surgery prefers suturing with nylon 10-0?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Extracapsular cataract extraction Suturing with nylon 10-0 is preferred in extracapsular cataract extraction.

questions.text: A male patient complained of visual disturbances. On examination, the light reflex is absent but the accommodation reflex is present, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neurosyphillis The clinical picture where his pupils accommodate but do not react to light is called Argyll Robertson pupil. It is seen in neurosyphillis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertical diplopia upon climbing downstairs. On examination, he tilts his head on his shoulder while going downstairs. Which is the cranial nerve involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cranial nerve 4 The patient is suffering from a weak superior oblique and the cranial nerve involved in CN 4.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with complaints of long-standing dacrocystitis. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dacrocystorhinostomy The treatment of choice for long-standing chronic dacryocystitis is dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery. It involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Malignant melanoma Malignant melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults.

questions.text: A patient complains of visual blurring which is relieved on its own. Fundus examination showed papilledema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amaurosis fugax Visual blurring in papilledema is called amaurosis fugax. Amaurosis fugax is the transient loss of vision due to an interruption in the blood supply to the retina or brain by emboli or spasms. The onset is abrupt and may follow a falling curtain pattern. The symptoms are relieved upon removal of the insult or the emboli and they recover in the same pattern the vision loss occurred.

choices.text: Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR)
Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior oblique (I0)
Right medial rectus (MR) and left medial rectus (MR)
Right medial rectus (MR) and right lateral rectus (LR)

questions.text: Which among the following are the yoke muscles of levodepression?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR) Right superior oblique (SO) and left inferior rectus (IR) are the yoke muscle pair for levodepression.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital with complaints of visual disturbances. On examination, there is iron deposits in his eye. What is the most likely diagnosis behind this occular finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Siderosis bulbi The presence of iron deposits in the eye especially in Industrial workers is called siderosis bulbi. It refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and causing atrophy.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient comes to the OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. On fundoscopy, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema were found. What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Grade IV Cotton wool spots and flame shaped hemorrage with disc edema is seen in grade IV of hypertensive retinopathy.

questions.text: Which is the drug of choice for refractive testing in a child with squint?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1% atropine 1% atropine is the drug of choice in refractive testing in a child with a squint.

questions.text: A patient complains that he cannot see the left side of both his eyes. But his central vision seems to be working fine. What is the visual field defect in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing Visual field defect involving the same left or right sides of each eye with central vision preserved is called Bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. It occurs in lesions of occipital lobe

questions.text: A child presented to the OPD with a characteristic type of cataract as seen in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Galactosemia The image shown below shows an oil drop cataract seen in galactosemia. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

questions.text: What is the dye used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens in cataract surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Trypan blue Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility. It is used in anterior capsulotomy like capsulorrhexis.

questions.text: A child has elevated liver enzyme levels. A ring-like structure is noted on ocular examination as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the cause for this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Copper This clinical scenario of elevated liver enzymes and Kayser-Fleischer {KF} ring seen in the image is suggestive of Wilson1s disease. KF ring is formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet's membrane of the cornea. Wilsons disease: The autosomal-recessive disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase. Clinical symptoms: • Hepatitis and cirrhosis • Behavioral disturbances • Wing beating tremor • Ophthalmic characteristics: o Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract o KF ring

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD the given visual field defect. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 3 The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma marked as 3 in the image given. Options marked in the image are: 1. Left optic nerve 3. Otic chiasma 4. Left optic tract 5. Left lateral geniculate nucleus Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumors. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumors like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Removal by 26G needle A history of injury to the eye while welding along with the the given image is suggestive of a superficial foreign body in the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in the management of this patient. Foreign bodies, which are usually small particles of dust, iron, steel, etc., may impinge upon the conjunctiva or cornea and cause sudden discomfort and reflex blinking. The foreign body sticks to the palpebral conjunctiva and is liable to be dragged across the cornea, causing excoriation. Particles of steel and iron fly straight onto the cornea and penetrate the epithelium or substantia propria.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye along with leukocoria and an absent red reflex. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which is the causative gene in the given condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rb gene The clinical history and histology point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma which occurs due to a mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14. Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision. Clinical features of retinoblastoma: • Present within the first two years of life • Leukocoria • Strabismus • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre­ septal cellulitis. • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases. • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

questions.text: Which of the following is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Left medial rectus The right lateral rectus and left medial rectus represent a pair of yoke muscles. Yoke muscles are also known as contralateral synergists. They are pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements. Version movements also known as conjugate movements are synchronous (simultaneous) symmetric movements of both eyes in the same direction.

questions.text: An 3-year old child is having amblyopia in right eye. What is the preferred treatment for this child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Occlusion therapy The treatment of amblyopia in this child is by occlusion of the normal eye, in this case, the left eye. Amblyopia or 'lazy eye' is a developmental defect of spatial visual processing that occurs in the central visual pathways of the eye. It is reversible if treated appropriately at the right time during the development phase (0-8 years of age) but is most commonly seen in the first 3 years of life. It is a condition with unilateral or bilateral subnormal vision without any local abnormality in the eye.

questions.text: Fundoscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CRAO The given fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO): Risk factors include: • Heart disease • Carotid artery disease • Mucormycosis • Varicella infection • Radiation exposure • Trauma

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstay of the management of trachoma. What does the S in this acronym represent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Surgery Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). The S in the acronym stands for surgery and involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done. Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who was using presbyopic glasses for the past few years is now able to comfortably read the newspaper without the glasses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Index myopia The clinical scenario of improvement in near vision of a presbyopic patient is termed the second sight phenomenon. This is seen due to index myopia caused by the formation of nuclear cataracts. Presbyopia, also known as the eyesight of old age, is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation leading to a progressive fall in near vision. The treatment of presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

questions.text: A patient presents with right sided field defects in both eyes, bur central vision emains unaffected. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problems and has a history of cataract surgery. OCT finding is shown below. What is the syndrome most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- B

questions.text: The cover-uncover test is powfermed to diagnose various eye conditions. Which of the following is NOT etected by this test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- D

questions.text: Which of the following is a side effect of PG analogue?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A 5 -year-old child presents with a refractive error of +1Dn the left eye <- 2D i the right eye. . Fundus examination reveals normal visual acuity and retinal idings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- C

questions.text: A patient sustainec blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ag and now presents with blurring of vision. What is the most likely conditions
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby is brought by the mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down during breastfeeding or thumb sucking, which disappears when the baby is not being fed. What is the most likely diagnosig?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A patient has a history of a flying foreign body injury to the eye. Ocular findings revealed iris pigmentation. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the deposition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

choices.text: The image is erect and real
The condenser lens needs to be kept close to the eye

questions.text: Which of the following sratements is correct regarding indirect ophthalmoscony?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- D

questions.text: A patient presents with breathlessness and is diagnosed with a Pancoast tumo. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- D

questions.text: A patient presents with proptosis that increases when bending down. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A patient visits emergency with history of trauma and following radiological image is obtaine: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of diabetes presents with cataracts. Which of the following metabolic products is primarily responsible for cataract formation in this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- C

questions.text: A corneal wisp test was performed, and the corneal reflex was elicited. Which of the following nerves is responsible for the afferent limb of this reflex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- B

questions.text: A patient visits emergency with history of blunt trauma and following radiological image is obtained: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Blow-out fracture of floor of orbit due to blunt trauma Posteromedial aspect of maxillary bone fracture is weakest point of orbit- involved in blow-out fracture. Eyeball goes inside – enophthalmous Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia is there Mechanical entrapment within the fracture of the inferior rectus or inferior oblique muscle, leading to difficulty in elevation. Also, diplopia is max on looking up.

questions.text: Which refractive error is in a patient with complains of eye strain with image depicting the focus of rays in different meidians in eye
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sturm conoid is for astigmatism Horizontal and vertical axis are focused at 2 different points In myopia and hyperopia: rays are focused at single point Presbyopia is near point concept

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the superior limbus of a patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Healed follicle leading to depressions in upper limbus in trachoma is Herbert pits Lymphoid infiltration with vascularization of the margin of the cornea in trachoma is known as pannus Horner Tranta are white dots containing eosinophils, epithelial debris in Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

questions.text: In a patient with pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma, what is the most likely visual field defect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Optic chiasma is compressed in pituitary adenoma. Nasal fibres of optic nerve crosses at chiasma, leading to temporal defects in both fields

questions.text: A high myopic patient presents with sudden onset of floaters and flashes in one eye, followed by a curtain like shadow in front of visual field. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The symptoms in a classic case of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are floaters – flashes – visual field defect followed by vision loss. Liquified vitreous can escape from the retinal break/hole into subretinal space and push the neurosensory retina (concave configuration)

questions.text: A 10 yearold presents with decreased vision. Posterior staphyloma was seen on Indirect ophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pathological myopia is associated with a high myopic of more than 6 D of myopia Features include: Lattice is area of retinal thinning Lacquer crack are cracks in Bruch membrane Choroidal new vessels can develop from it Foster Fuch spots: remnant of bleeding Chorioretinal atrophy: tigroid fundus (due to prominent choroid vessels) Posterior staphyloma: Degenerative high axial myopia is a major cause Perpapillary atrophy Tilted disc due to oblique insertion of optic nerve to disc

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset severe eye pain, headache, blurred vision, and coloured haloes. Examination reveals a mid-dilated pupil, hazy cornea and high intraocular pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) When pupil is mid dilated such as in dim light, prone position or by cycloplegics (mydriatics), there is increased apposition surface contact between iris and lens, causing relative pupillary block with aqueous in posterior chamber pushing the iris forward and blocks the angle of the anterior chamber, leading to an attack of acute angle closure. Pupil is dilated in acute angle closure Pupil is smal irregular in anterior uveitis

questions.text: A patient presented with painful blurred vision with photophobia after wearing contact lens. Slit-lamp exam reveals corneal stromal ring like infiltrates. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ring like infiltrates with contact lens is seen in Acanthamoeba Overall most common with contact lens associated ulcer is Pseudomonas

questions.text: A patient presents with redness in one eye with photophobia. On slit-lamp exam, a branched ulcer with desquamation is seen. There were reduced corneal sensation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Decreased corneal sensations is seen in viral keratitis Linear branching is seen in Herpes simplex

questions.text: A patient presents with a painful eyelid swelling. With pus pointing at the base of the eyelash. What is the most likely gland involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Zeiss is present at base of eyelash which can be involved in stye/external hordeolum Meibomian is present in tarsus, involved in chalazion and internal hordeolum

questions.text: The following image depicts which of the following squint
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right eye is deviated outwards: Exotropia Corneal reflex is at limbus: 45 degrees /90 prism dioptres of deviation If reflex is at pupil: 15 degree/30 PD If reflex is between pupil and limbus: 30 degrees/60 PD

questions.text: A child with ptosis and deviated eyes is likely to have which nerve palsy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ptosis is seen only in 3rd nerve palsy Also, eye is down and out

questions.text: A 45 year old patient with eye examination findings showing pupil reaction to near reflex but absent on light. Where is likely lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neurosyphillis affects pretectal nucleus and cause Argyll Roberston Pupil, where light near dissociation is seen. It affects the pupillary light reflex pathway Pupillary reflex (light reflex) – both direct and indirect – are absent but spares the more ventral pupillary near reflex pathway (Light – near dissociation)

questions.text: A 45 year old patiemt with eye examination findings as deep anterior chamber and jet black pupil. +11D glasses were prescribed to the patient. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Plus lenses are given in hypermetropia Aphakia has deep anterior chamber with jet black pupil and high plus number glasses are given Aphakia is high hypermetropia
